There may be eloquence that is not beneficial, does not rely on true principles, increases afflictions, does not exhaust afflictions, increases birth and death, and does not praise the merits and benefits of nirvana.
Maitreya!
Such eloquence is reprimanded by all Buddhas and is disapproved by all Buddhas.
At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If there is eloquence that increases birth and death, it is not the eloquence of the Buddha.

The Buddha said:
Maitreya!
For this reason, you should know that all the Buddhas' teachings are the Buddha's own eloquence. You should see it in this way.

If there is something to be said, it is in order to fulfill the factors of enlightenment that the bodhisattva is taught to benefit and praise those who take on the flow of cyclic existence, in order to benefit the bodhisattva.
Why is it so?
Maitreya!

The bodhisattva who is afflicted should see it like this: this bodhisattva does not commit the offense of this affliction, because he has mastery over the meaning and has also attained mastery over the Dharma.

If there is affliction without benefit, it does not fulfill the causes and conditions of the factors of enlightenment, and it is not a cause for the door of wholesome roots.
In that, the bodhisattva should not begrudge his body and life, and he should not follow that affliction.
Why is it so?
Maitreya!
The bodhisattva who has attained the power of wisdom has a different object of perception, while those who see there are afflictions have a different attachment to conditioned things.
Maitreya Bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

According to my understanding of the meaning of the Buddha's teachings, if there are bodhisattvas who do not wish to create karmic hindrances, who wish to exhaust karmic hindrances, who wish to be without deficiency or harm and attain liberation, they should have faith in the bodhisattva practices in the future, they should contemplate, not seek others' faults, always seek meritorious deeds, and seek the true and genuine.
The Buddha said:
So it is, so it is!
Maitreya!
The bodhisattvas of the later age should contemplate the bodhisattva practices and understand the skillful means.
Why is it so?
The skillful means and wisdom practiced by bodhisattvas are difficult to understand.
Maitreya!

It is like a stream-enterer who, among the practices of ordinary beings, manifests the stage of a stream-enterer, separate from ordinary beings, separate from the afflictions of desire, anger, and delusion. Those ordinary beings will fall into evil destinies, but those afflictions do not cause the noble disciples to fall into evil destinies, because they have realized this.
Maitreya!
It is just so!
The bodhisattvas of wisdom practice have not yet exhausted the defilements and habits, so they have a separate stage, separate from the stage of the beginner bodhisattvas.
Why is it so?
Their minds do not dwell in the mental afflictions, yet ordinary beings are attached to the mental afflictions, and due to delusion, they are unable to skillfully understand the place of liberation.
Maitreya!
The bodhisattvas of wisdom practice, although they have grave offenses, will extinguish them like ashes through the power of wisdom, and will not fall into evil destinies because of them.
Maitreya!
It is like a blazing fire, if you throw large pieces of firewood into it, and do this again and again, the fire will become even more blazing and will not go out.
It is just like this, Maitreya!

When the fire of wisdom of the wisdom-practicing bodhisattva blazes, if you throw conditioned afflictions into the fire of wisdom, the fire of wisdom will become even more blazing and will not go out, because of the power of wisdom.
Maitreya!
Because of this, you should know that the practice of the wisdom-practicing bodhisattvas is difficult to know.
At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
For the beginner bodhisattvas who have not yet attained the power of wisdom and have left the household life, what kinds of dharmas should they abandon?
What kinds of dharmas should they be close to?
If a bodhisattva is close to them, the power of wisdom that has not yet arisen will be caused to arise, and that which has arisen will increase and not decrease.
The Buddha said:
Maitreya!

The newly practicing bodhisattvas who have left home but have not yet attained the power of wisdom, although they have abandoned material wealth and offerings, should contemplate the faults of gain and fame and quickly abandon them. They should abandon worldly talk and contemplate the faults of worldly talk. They should abandon the delight in speaking much and contemplate the faults of speaking much. They should abandon the delight in sleep and contemplate the faults of sleep. They should abandon the delight in creating various activities and contemplate the faults of worldly activities. They should abandon the delight in play and contemplate the faults of delighting in play.
Having abandoned gain and fame, they should practice contentment with few desires and should associate with those who are content with few desires.
Having abandoned worldly talk, they should associate with those who delight in solitary practice.
Having abandoned speaking much, they should contemplate the true meaning.
Having abandoned sleep, they should be vigilant throughout the first and last watches of the night.
Having abandoned the delight in creating activities, they should associate with supramundane dharmas.
Having abandoned the joy of play, one should cultivate the compassion of joy without sentient beings.
Maitreya!

The newly practicing bodhisattva who has left home and renounced the world, who has not yet attained the power of wisdom, who wishes to attain the power of wisdom, should abandon such dharmas, and should be close to such dharmas.

Maitreya!ğŸ”½For the newly practicing bodhisattva who has left home and renounced the world, who has not yet reached the power of wisdom, who has not yet abandoned gain and fame, who has not yet been close to contentment with few desires, if wisdom has not yet arisen, it cannot be made to arise, and if it has already arisen, it cannot be made to increase and grow - this is impossible.

If one has not yet left worldly talk, has not yet been close to solitary practice, has not abandoned the joy of sleep, and is not close to the joy of being alert in the first and last watches of the night, and delights in engaging in activities, then during this time one will not be able to cultivate supramundane dharmas, will not abandon playfulness, will not be close to the thought of compassion without sentient beings, and if wisdom has not yet arisen, it cannot be made to arise, and if it has already arisen, it cannot be made to increase and grow - this is impossible.
Maitreya!

Therefore, if there are bodhisattvas who wish to give rise to the power of wisdom, those bodhisattvas should abandon all dharmas that should be abandoned, and should cultivate and practice all dharmas that should be cultivated and practiced.
Why is it so?
Maitreya!
Wisdom arises from causes. Without causes, wisdom cannot arise.
Causes do not combine, and it is impossible to easily give rise to [wisdom].
At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How should bodhisattvas contemplate the faults of material gain and fame?
What are the faults of material gain and fame that bodhisattvas should contemplate, and when they do so, they should be content and have no regrets?
The Buddha told Maitreya:

Contemplating in this way, because of material gain, desire arises, which harms one's own practice, and the faults of the mind giving rise to anger and resentment.

Bodhisattvas should contemplate material gain in this way. Having contemplated material gain,
When contemplating in this way, one's mind delights in few desires and is able to be without regret.
Why is this?
Maitreya!

Bodhisattvas with few desires do not have these faults. They will become vessels for the Buddha's teachings, and will not be deceived or looked down upon by monastics or laypeople. They will be fearless and attain pure faith. They will have no fear of any evil paths and will not be subdued. The wise bodhisattva, contemplating such merits, should distance himself from material gain and fame, abide with a right mind in contentment, and extinguish all greed and desire.

I have abandoned my body countless times, seeking the causes for unsurpassed enlightenment,

Everything, everywhere, should be abandoned, and also not engaging in defiled speech,
They have no enjoyment in the supreme Dharma, which is difficult to attain even in a hundred eons.
If one wishes to liberate and cultivate merit, do not ask about worldly activities,
Not for one's own benefit, without nirvana, if there is a question, it is for clothing and food,
